awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH-PGR:  Phenotypic and Genomic Diversity of North American Vitis
awd_abstract_narration:
The relationship between genome evolution and adaptation to stress has become increasingly important as environments change. Grapes (Vitis vinifera) are among the most important horticultural crops in the world, with over 1 million acres planted in the United States. Products of grape cultivation (table grapes, raisins, juice, wine and oil) have a value of $5.76 billion at the farm gate and an estimated $162 billion annually to the American economy. The viticulture industry has grown steadily over the past decade, but grape cultivation faces new and continuing challenges from diseases and abiotic stresses.  Grape cultivation relies heavily on wild North American species for rootstocks, and that reliance is expanding.  This project will allow researchers to determine the genetic composition of four wild grape species from the Southwest that are used, or have demonstrated promise, for grape breeding. The project will gather information about the ability of these species to resist Pierces Disease, it will generate new information about plant biology, genomics, and evolution, and it will make Vitis one of the best-studied botanical genera. Data obtained from this project will help worldwide grape breeding programs and will be available through a community resource, allowing the project investigators to share their research with members of the public and the wine and grape industries. They will also train and mentor undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. The PIs work at public universities known for their efforts to broaden participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields and serving first generation college students.  

The cultivation, sustainability and security of grapes (Vitis vinifera) rely heavily on North American Vitis species as sources of resistance to abiotic and biotic stresses. This project aims to make Vitis a leading perennial model for comparative genomics, landscape genomics and association genomics. It will also further understanding of the basic biology of resistance to Pierces Disease, which is critical for the sustainability of viticulture. Researchers will assay hundreds of natural accessions to identify plants with resistance and study the geographic distribution of resistance in nature. They will complement phenotypic assays with whole genome resequencing (WGS) data to identify signatures of local adaptation, study the phylogenomics of the genus, and associate genetic variation with climatic variables. They will also employ analyses that aim to uncover important basic information about candidate genes and the genetic architecture underlying abiotic and biotic stress responses. An additional goal is to generate reference genomes for four North American Vitis species that have been used in rootstock breeding; currently, no reference genomes exist for any North American Vitis species. These genomes will be a valuable community resource, facilitate interspecific analyses, form the basis for inferring the pace and pattern of structural rearrangements during species diversification, and aid the identification of homologous and syntenous regions between V. vinifera and its congeners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported research on genetic diversity in the genus Vitis. The genus Vitis includes the European domesticated grape, but it also encompasses ~30 North American wild grape species. The wild species are of both intellectual and agricultural interest. Agriculturally, a handful of wild species are used in viticulture as rootstocks. These rootstocks are used to help cultivate 90% or more of the grapes grown throughout the world, because they contribute important traits like salt tolerance and resistance to diseases. However, there is a need to better understand the agronomic potential of the vast diversity contained across the wild species. Intellectually, the North American species are interesting because they grow across many climates – from the Northeast US and parts of Canada to the American Southwest and the north of Mexico – and they can also all interbreed. They thus define an interesting mystery: how do they remain distinct species despite being able to interbreed, and has this interbreeding contributed to their ability to inhabit distinct climates? Do their genes help unlock puzzles about adaptation to diseases or other traits that might inform about processes of evolution?

Intellectual Merit:

To begin to address these questions, our research deciphered the genetics of a subset of the North American wild species by sequencing the genome of 9 different species. With these genomes, we constructed a pangenome of wild Vitis; this pangenome helped us understand genome evolution in the genus by identifying genetic differences between species. The pangenome is also an important resource for exploring relationships between genotypes and phenotypes. In addition to the genomes and the pangenome, we measured population genetic variation in several Vitis species. We combined our genetic data with measures of traits from individual plants, including the ability to resist a particular bacterial pathogen (Xylella fastidiosa) and to tolerate high salt concentrations.

With these data, our research discovered an array of biological phenomena. We identified, for example, the genes that contribute to the sex of flowers; these genes are of broad interest for both plant breeding and for understanding the evolution of plant mating systems. We also discovered genes that may lead to resistance to X. fastidiosa. These genes may provide the first known genetic tool to combat a pernicious bacterial threat that attacks not only grapevines but also almonds, olives and other crops. Interestingly, genes that confer resistance to diseases are often shared among species, suggesting that interbreeding serves to swap advantageous genetic materials. Finally, we also identified a gene that likely contributes to salt tolerance.

Our work also explored the genetic variants that associated with climate. The key conclusions were contributing to our understanding and prediction of genetic types that are likely to be able withstand climate change or that may be best adapted to tolerate climates in locations where viticulture may be imperiled due to climate change. These approaches have the promise of contributing to both the conservation of wild species and sustainable agriculture.

To perform our work, we also improved methodologies to assemble and annotate complete genomes, including a comprehensive pipeline and a novel approach to assembling separate haplotypes. These methods helped support our finding that long-standing clonal lineages accumulate deletions, so that in a clonal lineage many genes have only one allele, with the second allele missing.  

Broader Impacts:

In addition to our discoveries addressing a wide variety of biological phenomena, which we disseminated in prominent journals, our work has had additional impacts. One was training project personnel; the project contributed directly to the education and training of many personnel, including graduate students, postdocs and undergraduates. The work supported by this proposal provided a basis for training that led to four postdocs acquiring faculty or independent research positions. It also helped train students who went on to acquire prestigious funding for their postdoctoral studies.

In addition, work from this grant was presented and discussed in public lectures, primarily to growers and to the grape industry.  Project personnel gave scores of such lectures, hopefully with a substantive impact.
